<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
In the past, the mean length of a particular variety of worm has been \(10.3 \text{cm}\), with standard deviation \(2.6 \text{cm}\). Following a change in the climate, it is thought that the mean length of this variety of worm has decreased. The lengths of a random sample of 100 worms of this variety are found and the mean of this sample is found to be \(9.8 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 151, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
Assuming that the standard deviation remains at \(2.6 \text{cm}\), carry out a test at the \(2\%\) significance level of whether the mean length has decreased. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
The number of faults in cloth made on a certain machine has a Poisson distribution with mean \(2.4 \text{ per } 10 \text{ m}^2\). An adjustment is made to the machine. It is required to test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether the mean number of faults has decreased. A randomly selected \(30 \text{ m}^2\) of cloth is checked and the number of faults is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 611, 170]]<|/det|>
State suitable null and alternative hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 148, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 361, 460, 380]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 646, 92]]<|/det|>
Exactly 3 faults are found in the randomly selected \(30\mathrm{m}^2\) of cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 526, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
Later a similar test was carried out at the \(5\%\) significance level, using another randomly selected \(30\mathrm{m}^2\) of cloth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 146, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 558, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
Given that the number of faults actually has a Poisson distribution with mean 0.5 per \(10\mathrm{m}^2\), find the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 572, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 900, 92]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is a random variable with distribution B(10, 0.2). A random sample of 160 values of \(X\) is taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 900, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the approximate distribution of the sample mean, including the values of the parameters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 364, 185, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 363, 670, 381]]<|/det|>
Hence find the probability that the sample mean is less than 1.8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 363, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The masses, in grams, of small and large bags of flour have the distributions N(510, 100) and N(1015, 324) respectively. André selects 4 small bags of flour and 2 large bags of flour at random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 809, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total mass of these 6 bags of flour is less than \(4130\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total mass of the 4 small bags is more than the total mass of the 2 large bags.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
